If you are unable to attend your
COVID-19 test at one of Horizon's COVID-19 Assessment Centres due
to weather, please resubmit your request by visiting

or
call Tele-Care 811. Once you resubmit, you will be contacted with a
new appointment time.

COVID-19 Assessment Centres across Horizon offer appointments
for patients exhibiting mild to moderate symptoms of Coronavirus
(COVID-19).

are provided following a triage
completed by Tele-Care 811.

Assessment centres will help to reduce visits to emergency
departments and minimize the risk of transmission.

walk-in clinics. They will
complete COVID-19 screening and testing by appointment only.

Assessment centres are set up in Moncton, Saint John, Miramichi,
Fredericton and Upper River Valley.

If you are displaying mild or moderate symptoms of COVID-19,
complete the self-assessment by visiting

In an emergency, or if you are experiencing severe symptoms,
please call 911 or call ahead to your local Emergency Department so
they can prepare for your arrival.

If you've been directed to one of these sites
by Tele-Care 811, have a look at this virtual tour so you know what
to expect.

Drop-ins accepted. Testing is performed with or without an

Hours of Operation: Monday to Friday, 1 to 4 p.m.
How do I access the assessment centre?

Individuals can access the assessment centre by contacting
Tele-Care 811.

Following an assessment by Tele-Care, if/when the client
requires an in-person assessment a referral will be sent to a
COVID-19 Assessment Centre; the staff at the assessment centre will
contact the individual to schedule an appointment, this should be
completed within 24 hours, but it will depend on the number of
referrals.
What are the hours of operation?

Every effort will be made to screen as many individuals as
possible each day. The hours may vary as it will be dependent on
the volume of referrals received. These assessment centres are not
walk-in clinics, they

are accessed by appointment through
811 only
Please check in regularly for updates on our
What health care services are provided?

Individuals will receive access to screening, be directed to
further care if/when needed as well as provided with evidence-based
resources and information about COVID-19.

Drive throughs have been set up in Moncton, Fredericton and
Miramichi for initial screening. If/when a client requires more
intensive screening they will be asked to enter the assessment
centre. We are looking at this option for the other assessment
sites.

There will be a health care provider that is able to do an
assessment, provide medical advice and guidance, and complete the
screening test. The health care team may include a physician, nurse
practitioner, Registered Nurse or a Licensed Practical Nurse.

What's the difference between self-isolation and
self-monitoring related to Coronavirus (COVID-19)?

Have had a possible exposure to COVID-19 in the last 14
days

for a poster on self-monitoring, which
you can download and post on social media to and share with your
family and friends

Have travelled outside of New Brunswick or have had close
contact with someone diagnosed with COVID-19

for a poster on self-isolating, which you
can download and post on social media to share with your family and
friends.

Monitor yourself for 14 days for one or more symptoms of
COVID-19:

text:
Go about your day but remember to follow provincial guidelines
related to the State of Emergency.

If you need to go in public, maintain a two metre (six foot)
distance between yourself and others.

If you develop symptoms, isolate yourself from others (including
your household) immediately.

If you are displaying mild or moderate symptoms of COVID-19,
complete the self-assessment by visiting

or call Tele-Care 811.
They may refer you to one of the Community Assessment Centres for
testing.

Stay home and monitor your symptoms, even if mild, for 14
days.

Avoid contact with others (including your household) to prevent
the spread of disease in your home.

Here are some helpful items to have on hand during
self-isolation:
Waste basket with disposable, plastic liner
Medication to reduce fever (ibuprofen or acetaminophen)

Keep other members of your household safe and healthy by
cleaning and disinfecting surfaces that you touch often, such as
toilets, bedside tables, doorknobs, phones and television
remotes.

Why is Perth-Andover the only location accepting clients
without an appointment?

Drop-in service at the Perth-Andover location is a temporary
measure to encourage testing at for residents in the area at the
new, temporary COVID-19 Assessment Centre.

What do I do when I arrive for a drop-in appointment at the
Perth-Andover Assessment Centre?

First, you arrive at the Perth-Andover Baptist Church at 194
Barrett St. with your New Brunswick Medicare card.  Once you
arrive, drive towards the Horizon signage and staff will direct you
where to go. You'll remain in your vehicle for the entire
process.
